pages.text: Since time began, rouges and alchemists the world over have suffered from a vexing problem: potions and daggers don't stack. It's not their fault, it's just the way they're shaped. Fortunately, there is a simple solution: the humble bandolier $(br2) A bandolier is a strap of leather with small loops on it for holding useful yet unstackable items, including most potions, oils, and daggers.

Items can be inserted and extracted from bandoliers in all the usual bundle ways, and dropping a bandolier while crouching empties it. Right clicking a bandolier cycles the items, and shift right clicking places the first item in the bandolier into your other hand, assuming said hand is empty. $(br2) Whenever you consume a bandolier-compatible item, the first bandolier in your inventory will try to give you the first item in its inventory.

This feature works with any item that is bandolier compatible, which is potions, daggers, and the strange totems that evokers carry around. $(br2) You can also apparently make items compatible with a bandolier by "altering the tag", whatever that means. I don't think writing "diamond" on the tag of a shirt makes it armor. Anyways, I digress. $(br2) Bandoliers can be crafted with rabbit, and can be dyed any color.

Right clicking on a cauldron of water with a bandolier will wash off any dyes. $(br2) Up until recently, it was assumed that bandoliers were a modern invention. However, recent anthropological findings indicate that witch covens have been using bandoliers for centuries to compensate for their lack of an inventory.
